TI: The arithmetic of Carmichael quotients
DE: Carmichael function; Carmichael quotient; Carmichael-Wieferich number; Perfect nonlinear function
AB: Carmichael quotients for an integer are introduced analogous to Fermat quotients, by using Carmichael function . Various properties of these new quotients are investigated, such as basic arithmetic properties, sequences derived from Carmichael quotients, Carmichael-Wieferich numbers, and so on. Finally, we link Carmichael quotients to perfect nonlinear functions.

AU: Deszcz, R; Glogowska, M; Hotlos, M; Zafindratafa, G
AF: Deszcz, Ryszard; Glogowska, Malgorzata; Hotlos, Marian; Zafindratafa, Georges
TI: On some curvature conditions of pseudosymmetry type
DE: Einstein manifold; Quasi-Einstein manifold; Manifold with parallel Weyl tensor; Roter type manifold; Pseudosymmetric manifold; Generalized Einstein metric condition; Tachibana tensor
AB: It is known that the difference tensor and the Tachibana tensor of any semi-Riemannian Einstein manifold of dimension are linearly dependent at every point of . More precisely holds on . In the paper we show that there are quasi-Einstein, as well as non-quasi-Einstein semi-Riemannian manifolds for which the above mentioned tensors are linearly dependent. For instance, we prove that every non-locally symmetric and non-conformally flat manifold with parallel Weyl tensor (essentially conformally symmetric manifold) satisfies . Manifolds with parallel Weyl tensor having Ricci tensor of rank two form a subclass of the class of Roter type manifolds. Therefore we also investigate Roter type manifolds for which the tensors and are linearly dependent. We determine necessary and sufficient conditions for a Roter type manifold to be a manifold having that property.

TI: Weak parallelogram laws on banach spaces and applications to prediction
DE: Parallelogram law; Pythagorean theorem; Uniform convexity; Best predictor; Baxter's inequality; Purely nondeterministic
AB: This paper concerns a family of weak parallelogram laws for Banach spaces. It is shown that the familiar Lebesgue spaces satisfy a range of these inequalities. Connections are made to basic geometric ideas, such as smoothness, convexity, and Pythagorean-type theorems. The results are applied to the linear prediction of random processes spanning a Banach space. In particular, the weak parallelogram laws furnish coefficient growth estimates, Baxter-type inequalities, and criteria for regularity.

TI: More accurate Young, Heinz, and Holder inequalities for matrices
DE: Young inequality; Heinz inequality; Holder inequality; Hilbert-Schmidt norm; Unitarily invariant norm; Positive semidefinite matrix
ID: GEOMETRIC MEAN INEQUALITY; OPERATOR INEQUALITIES; NORM
AB: In this paper we deal with a more precise estimates for the matrix versions of Young, Heinz, and Holder inequalities. First we give an improvement of the matrix Heinz inequality for the case of the Hilbert-Schmidt norm. Then, we refine matrix Young-type inequalities for the case of Hilbert-Schmidt norm, which hold under certain assumptions on positive semidefinite matrices appearing therein. Finally, we give the refinement and the reverse of the matrix Holder inequality which holds for every unitarily invariant norm. As applications, we also obtain improvements of some well-known matrix inequalities in a quotient form. Our results are compared with the previously known from the literature.

TI: On the characteristic polynomials of linear functional equations
DE: Linear functional equations; Spectral analysis; Field homomorphisms
AB: The solutions of a linear functional equation are typically generalized polynomials. The existence of their non-trivial monomial terms strongly depends on the algebraic properties of some related families of parameters. In extremal cases (the parameters are algebraic numbers or the parameters form an algebraically independent system) we have elegant methods to decide the existence of non-trivial solutions. In this paper we are going to extend and unify the treatment of the existence problem by introducing the characteristic polynomials of a linear functional equation such that the algebraic properties of the roots allows us to conclude the existence of non-trivial solutions.

TI: On the Lucas sequence equation 1/U-n = Sigma k=1(infinity) Uk-1/x(k)
DE: Lucas sequences; Diophantine equations; Elliptic curves
ID: ELLIPTIC DIOPHANTINE EQUATIONS; ESTIMATING LINEAR-FORMS; INTEGER SOLUTIONS; FRACTIONS
AB: In 1953 Stancliff noted an interesting property of the Fibonacci number F-11 = 89. One has that 1/89 = 0/10 + 1/10(2) + 1/10(3) + 2/10(4) + 3/10(5) + 5/10(6) + ..., where in the numerators the elements of the Fibonacci sequence appear. We provide methods to determine similar identities in case of Lucas sequences. As an example we prove that 1/U-10 = 1/416020 = Sigma(infinity)(k=0) U-k/647(k+1), where U-0 = 0, U-1 = 1 and U-n = 4U(n-1) + Un-2, n >= 2.

TI: Dowker-type theorems for hyperconvex discs
DE: Approximation; Disc-polygons; Dowker-type theorems; Hyperconvexity
AB: A hyperconvex disc of radius is a planar set with nonempty interior that is the intersection of closed circular discs of radius . A convex disc-polygon of radius is a set with nonempty interior that is the intersection of a finite number of closed circular discs of radius . We prove that the maximum area and perimeter of convex disc--gons of radius contained in a hyperconvex disc of radius are concave functions of , and the minimum area and perimeter of disc--gons of radius containing a hyperconvex disc of radius are convex functions of . We also consider hyperbolic and spherical versions of these statements.

TI: Superadditivity of the Levinson functional and applications
DE: Levinson inequality; Jensen inequality; Levinson functional; Refinement; Converse
AB: We study the Levinson functional, constructed as a difference between the right-hand side and the left-hand side of the Levinson inequality. We show that it possesses the properties of superadditivity and monotonicity. As a consequence, we obtain mutual bounds for this functional, expressed via the non-weighted functional of the same type. In this way, a refinement and a converse of the Levinson inequality in a difference form is obtained.

TI: On congruence extension properties for ordered algebras
DE: Ordered algebra; Order-congruence; Compatible quasiorder; Congruence extension property; Quasiorder extension property; Amalgamation property; Transferability property
AB: We introduce four extension properties (CEP, QEP, SCEP and SQEP) for ordered algebras, similar to the congruence extension property (CEP) and the strong congruence extension property of usual (unordered) algebras. All four properties turn out to have a description in terms of commutative squares or pullback diagrams. We then use these categorical descriptions to prove an ordered analogue of the well-known relation TP = AP + CEP, namely that a variety of ordered algebras has the ordered transferability property if and only if it has the ordered amalgamation property and QEP.

TI: Pell equation and randomness
DE: Lattice point counting in specified regions; Discrepancy; Central limit theorem; Law of the iterated logarithm
ID: LATTICE POINT PROBLEMS; ITERATED LOGARITHM; SQUARE-ROOT; GIANT LEAP; LAW
AB: Finding the integer solutions of a Pell equation is equivalent to finding the integer lattice points in a long and narrow tilted hyperbolic region, located along a straight line passing through the origin with a quadratic irrational slope. The case of inhomogeneous Pell inequalities it is equivalent to finding the integer lattice points in translated copies of a long and narrow tilted hyperbolic region with a quadratic irrational slope. We prove randomness in these natural lattice point counting problems. We have two main results: a central limit theorem (Theorem 2.1) and a law of the iterated logarithm (Theorem 2.2). The classical Circle Problem (counting lattice points in large circles) is a notoriously difficult open problem. What our results show is that the hyperbolic analog of the Circle Problem is solvable with striking precision.

RP: Beck, J (reprint author), Rutgers State Univ, Dept Math, Hill Ctr, Busch Campus, New Brunswick, NJ 08903 USA.

TI: The classifying space of an inverse semigroup
DE: Generalized inverse semigroups; etale actions; Right normal bands
AB: We refine Funk's description of the classifying space of an inverse semigroup by replacing his -semigroups by right generalized inverse -semigroups. Our proof uses the idea that presheaves of sets over meet semilattices may be characterized algebraically as right normal bands.

TI: A Hardy-Littlewood integral inequality on finite intervals with a concave weight
DE: Integral inequality; HELP-type inequality; Concave weight function
AB: We prove: For all concave functions w : [a, b] -> [0,infinity) and for all functions f is an element of C-2[a, b] with f (a) = f (b) = 0 we have (integral(b)(a) w(x)f'(x)(2) dx)(2) <= (integral(b)(a) w(x)f(x)(2) dx)(integral(b)(a) w(x)f ''(x)(2) dx). Moreover, we determine all cases of equality.

AF: Bovdi, Victor; Grishkov, Alexander; Ursul, Mihail
TI: On the endomorphism rings of abelian groups and their Jacobson radical
DE: Topological ring; Jacobson radical; Quasi-injective module; Endomorphism ring; Admissible topology; Bohr topology; Liebert topology; Finite topology; Functorial topology; Shift homomorphism
AB: We give a characterization of those abelian groups which are direct sums of cyclic groups and the Jacobson radicals of their endomorphism rings are closed. A complete characterization of p-groups A for which is locally compact, where is the Liebert topology on is given. We prove that if A is a countable elementary p-group then has a non-admissible ring topology. To every functorial topology on A a right bounded ring topology on is attached. By using this topology we construct on a non-metrizable and non-admissibe ring topology for elementary countable p-groups A.

TI: The crossing number of chordal ring networks
DE: Chordal ring; Crossing number; Planar graph; Good drawing; Optimal drawing
AB: The chordal ring network of order n, denoted by , is the graph with vertex set , an additive group of integers modulo n, and adjacencies given by for all even vertex i and distinct odd integers x, y, z in . The crossing number of a network(graph) is closely related to the minimum layout area required for the implementation of a VLSI circuit for that network. From this perspective, the analysis of crossing numbers of graphs makes most sense when one focuses on networks(graphs) that have good properties as interconnection networks. In this paper, we study the crossing number of the chordal ring networks for all even n >= 10.

TI: On pseudorandom binary sequences constructed by using finite fields
DE: Binary sequences; Pseudorandomness; Finite fields; Well-distributions; Correlation
AB: By using finite fields of order with and their quadratic characters, Sarkozy and Winterhof presented a construction for binary sequences of length with strong pseudorandom properties. In the special case Gyarmati improved on their estimates for the pseudorandom measures of these sequences. Here we extend Gyarmati's result and sharpen the estimates of Sarkozy and Winterhof for any prime power p(r).

TI: Pseudorandomness of binary sequences derived from linear recursions
DE: Pseudorandomness; Pseudorandom measures; Linear recursion
AB: In this paper we study the pseudorandomness of finite binary sequences derived from linear recursions. We show, that the well-distribution measures of these sequences are small. Furthermore we also show that the correlation measures of these sequences are small for small correlation orders, but if the order of the correlation is greater than the order of the linear recursion, then the correlation can be large.
